thread.title: Teenage mum arrested after baby boy 'found abandoned in pram outside Co-op supermarket'
thread.title_full: Teenage mum arrested after baby boy 'found abandoned in pram outside Co-op supermarket'

author: Chris kitching
title: Teenage mum arrested after baby boy 'found abandoned in pram outside Co-op supermarket'
text:
The Co-op store in Canterbury Road, Whitstable, Kent (stock picture) (Photo: Googlemaps) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A teenage mum has been arrested after she allegedly abandoned her baby boy in a pram outside a supermarket on a busy road. 
Kent Police were called after a member of the public reported concern for the welfare of the child and young mother. 
An eyewitness said officers took the baby into their care and changed its nappy when they arrived at the Co-op store in Canterbury Road, Whitstable, Kent, around 6:30pm on Tuesday. 
They then launched a search for the mum, who is believed to be 18-years-old, as temperatures dropped. Officers took the baby into their care when they arrived at the supermarket (Photo: Googlemaps) 
The mum was located and arrested a short time later. 
Eyewitness Alison Barrett, of Herne Bay, said the officers had to change the child's nappy. 
She posted on Facebook: "Poor baby left in the co op in whitstable hope they find the mum safe and can help them." 
She added: "Luckily it won't do any harm to the baby long term and he was playing and laughing with the police officer there so not upset or distressed." 
A police spokesman said: "Kent Police received a report of concern for the welfare of a woman who was last seen outside a supermarket in Canterbury Road, Whitstable, on Tuesday 3 January 2017 at around 6.20pm. 
"The caller also told police there was an unaccompanied child at the location. 
"Officers carried out a search of the area and located the woman shortly afterwards. 
"She has been arrested in connection with the incident and remains in custody." Like us on Facebook
